title: C04-1128

sentences.text: While sentence extraction as an approach to summarization has been shown to work in documents of certain genres , because of the conversational nature of email communication where utterances are made in relation to one made previously , sentence extraction may not capture the necessary segments of dialogue that would make a summary coherent .
In this paper , we present our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization .
We show that various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing .

Entity-our_work_on_the_detection_of_ques.label: our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization
aliases: our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization
Entity-our_work_on_the_detection_of_ques.description: The research presented in this paper that focuses on detecting and utilizing question-answer pairs within email conversations to improve email summarization.

mentions.local_name: our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization

Entity-we_show.label: We show
Entity-we_show.description: The results or findings presented in this paper that demonstrate how various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing.

Entity-various_feature_based_on_the_stru.label: various features based on the structure of email-threads
aliases: various features based on the structure of email-threads
Entity-various_feature_based_on_the_stru.description: Structural characteristics derived from the organization and relationships within email conversations that can enhance the detection of question-answer pairs.

mentions.local_name: various features based on the structure of email-threads

Entity-lexical_similarity_of_discourse_s.label: lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing
aliases: lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing
Entity-lexical_similarity_of_discourse_s.description: A methodology for measuring the semantic connection between adjacent text passages in an email conversation, with a focus on identifying pairs of questions and answers.

mentions.local_name: lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing

Entity-the_task_of_email_summarization.label: the task of email summarization
Entity-the_task_of_email_summarization.description: The process of condensing and extracting key information from emails to create a concise summary.

aliases: sentence extraction as an approach to summarization
Entity-sentence_extraction_a_an_approach.description: The process or technique of extracting and summarizing information from text by identifying key sentences.

Entity-task_of_email_summarization.label: task of email summarization
Entity-task_of_email_summarization.description: The process of condensing and highlighting essential information from emails to convey their key points or main ideas.

aliases: features based on the structure of email-threads
Entity-feature_based_on_the_structure_of.description: A set of characteristics or attributes derived from the organization and pattern of emails in a thread.

summary: While sentence extraction as an approach to summarization has been shown to work in documents of certain genres , because of the conversational nature of email communication where utterances are made in relation to one made previously , sentence extraction may not capture the necessary segments of dialogue that would make a summary coherent . In this paper , we present our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization . We show that various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing .

Predicate-has_been_shown_to_work_in.label: has been shown to work in
Predicate-has_been_shown_to_work_in.description: This predicate indicates that a process or method (subject) has demonstrated effectiveness within a specific context or domain (object), implying a successful application or implementation.

Predicate-improve_upon.label: improve upon
Predicate-improve_upon.description: To enhance or surpass something by making it better, more effective, or more advanced. The predicate 'improve upon' indicates a relationship where the subject takes an existing entity (the object) and enhances its quality, performance, or value.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or displays information, ideas, or work to others. It suggests that the object being presented is new, noteworthy, or significant in some way.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or encompasses a more general concept or category represented by the object. This relationship suggests a hierarchical connection between the two entities, where the subject can be seen as a specific instance or subclass of the broader term.
